newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary struck depository deal with Cedel Bank.
newsitem.headline: Hungary struck depository deal with Cedel Bank.

text.p: Hungary's central clearing and depositary house Keler Rt signed a depository agreement with the Luxembourg-based international clearing and settlement bank Cedel Bank, the partners said on Monday.
Hungarian beneficiaries of the agreement, including the Budapest Stock Exchange, expect increased investments here as a result of the deal.

"The access to the Hungarian securities market via Cedel Bank in itself raises the status of the market and separates it from those of other emerging markets," Keler's General Manager Peter Basch told a news conference.
"As a result (of the deal) we expect substantial portfolio investments to appear on the Hungarian market," Basch said.

This link, which goes into effect from October 7, will allow Cedel Bank clients to settle their Hungarian securities transactions through the direct Cedel Bank-Keler connection, Keler said in a statement.
The agreement also includes ING Bank, which acts as cash correspondent bank.
Keler, which officially became national depository in July 1995, was rated an eligible depository last December under the U.S. Investment Company Act.

Keler opened an account with Cedel Bank in June this year to take advantage of new investment opportunities offered when Hungary became a member of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in March, it said.

The arrangement enables Hungarian investors to settle their foreign securities transactions via Keler as well as to exercise their relevant rights, obtain cash proceeds and other investment entitlements, it said.
